items.synopsis: Alan Joyce reportedly jets off with a substantial amount of cash and Qantas shares in his portfolio — but valid questions are being asked about whether he is entitled to all of it.

title.children: Hail, snow and gales to replace spring heat in a battle of the seasons

image.altText: An older man wearing a blue suit and tie and glasses sits in a room with a portrait of Australia's Parliament House behind him.

items.synopsis: Outgoing RBA governor Philip Lowe will give his final public speech before handing over to Michele Bullock next week, while Wall Street fell after economic data prompted concerns interest rates will stay higher for longer. Follow live.

title.children: Philip Lowe to give final speech as RBA governor, ASIC sues PayPal Australia, ASX lower on overseas interest rate fears

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market has opened lower, down 0.8% to 7,197 points as of 10:25am AEST — the lowest open the ASX has seen in seven days. (For live updates at any time, head to the top of the blog and open the pinned post.) Those jitters from Wall Street overnight about sticky inflation and higher interest rates for longer have flowed through to our session, in response to that stronger-than-expected US services sector figures. Academic and education services and real estate are the only sectors in the black so far — they're up 0.5% and 0.1% respectively. Basic materials is down 2% so far, while industrials has dipped by 0.7%, and consumer cyclicals fell by 0.5%. As for the top five performers so far: Liontown Resources +5.1% Chalice Mining +3.5% Beach Energy +3.1% Viva Energy +1.65 Resmed +1.1% And the bottom five performers: Super Retail Group -6.2% BrainChip Holdings -4% BHP Group -4% Perpetual -3.6% Reliance Worldwide -3.1% (Take BHP's performance with a grain of salt today, though — they are trading ex-dividend.)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX falls to 7-day low as Wall Street jitters send miners lower

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: when is the final speech happening.  I will miss him and his honesty.  Will the speech be aired live? - Elizabeth. Hi Elizabeth, Philip Lowe will be speaking at 1:05pm AEST at a lunch for the Anika Foundation in Sydney. You will be able to listen to audio of his speech live through a link on the RBA's website, but we are also going to be bringing you all the action from his speech right (and Q+A session after) right here on the blog. (Behind the scenes, we are also working on trying to get live streamed video happening — watch this space!)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The competition and consumer watchdog has launched legal action against online dating site eHarmony for allegedly making misleading statements about the price, renewal and duration of its memberships. The ACCC claims eHarmony stated it offered "free dating", its memberships automatically renewed, and failed to display accurate prices, statements about "one month" memberships and early cancellation options. The watchdog alleges the conduct dates back to at least November 2019, and "most of it is ongoing". ACCC chair Gina Cass-Gottlieb says the watchdog has received "hundreds" of complaints about eHarmony and its memberships. "We allege that eHarmony deprived consumers of the chance to make an informed choice about whether to join this dating service and how much to spend in doing so," Ms Cass-Gottlieb said. “We allege that as a result of eHarmony's conduct, consumers may have thought they committed to a plan of 6, 12 or 24 months when in reality the plan was longer because it automatically renewed, in some cases at a much higher price." Ms Cass-Gottlieb also said eHarmony's free membership had limited functionality that required customers to pay before being able to date, and misled members about their ability to cancel subscriptions. She added that eHarmony should have known about the need for clear information for members, as the ACCC consulted the dating site in 2016 when developing its best practice guidelines for dating websites. "We are disappointed to have to take this action, especially since eHarmony should have been well and truly on notice about the need to provide consumers with clear and accurate information about their dating services," Ms Cass-Gottlieb said. The ACCC is also encouraging customers who experienced issues with an eHarmony subscription, or paid more than what was advertised for a membership to contact them via their website. eHarmony has been contacted for comment.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: eHarmony hit with ACCC action for alleged 'subscription trap' and misleading prices

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The opposition says the federal government still has questions to answer about why it did not allow extra Qatar flights into Australia. The airline wanted an extra 28 flights per week into major capital cities, but that was denied in July this year. Transport Minister Catherine King says there were many factors that lead to her decision which was in "the national interest." Shadow Finance Minister Jane Hume told RN Breakfast that answer wasn't good enough. "Quite frankly I don't think that it's any clearer today than it was yesterday, what was behind the decision to deny Qatar Airways additional routes to Australia that would have increased competition and decreased the price of airfares for ordinary Australians." You can listen to the full interview of RN Breakfast at the link below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Still a lot of questions to answer' over Qatar, Hume says

featuredLink.title: Hume: 'still a lot of questions to answer' over Qatar - ABC listen

props.alt: A close up of Jane Hume speaking.

children.content: The opposition says the federal government still has questions to answer about why it did not allow extra Qatar flights into Australia.
The airline wanted an extra 28 flights per week into major capital cities, but that was denied in July this year.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext:
By political reporter Tom Lowrey Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is expected to sit down with China's Premier Li Qiang on the sidelines of the ASEAN summit in Jakarta this morning, in what would be the highest-level meeting between the two countries this year. Premier Li is China's second-highest-ranking official after President Xi Jinping, who has opted not to attend a series of global summits underway this week. There had been hopes Albanese might meet President Xi at the G20 leader's summit in Delhi this weekend, re-creating a significant meeting of the two leaders at last year's G20 summit in Bali. But with that no longer an option, it is now expected the PM will meet Premier Li instead. It's anticipated the two leaders would meet ahead of the East Asia Summit, which brings together South-East Asian leaders with leaders of countries like Australia, Japan, China, Russia and the USA. While diplomatic and trade relations between Australia and China have improved substantially in recent months, there are some substantial issues that might be raised. Trade barriers remain in place on Australian wine exports, and ministers have spoken out in recent months calling for their removal. Two Australians also remain detained in Beijing —
journalist Cheng Lei, and writer Dr Yang Hengjun. The government has openly called for both Australians to be reunited with their families, and Foreign Minister Penny Wong yesterday told the ABC that officials were continuing that pressure. "We are deeply concerned about Ms Cheng Lei and Dr Yang, as are so many Australians," she said. "And we have continued to raise with our counterparts at every level the desire of Australia to see both Ms Cheng Lei and Dr Yang reunited with their families. "We'll continue to make those representations."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM expected to meet China's second-highest-ranking official in Indonesia

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: YEAH. THE. GIRLS. Matildas stars Sam Kerr and Hayley Raso have been nominated for 2022-23 Women's Ballon d'or, which is awarded to the best female footballer in 2023. It's the first time two Australians have reached the shortlist for football's most prestigious individual award. Matildas captain and Chelsea star Kerr has been nominated every year since the Women's Ballon d'or was introduced in 2018, while it's Raso's first nomination. Spain and Barcelona midfielder Aitana Bonmati is the favourite, having recently claimed the UEFA Player of the Year award ahead of Kerr.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Matildas stars Sam Kerr and Hayley Raso nominated for Women's Ballon d'or
